The Council threw that big amnesty after I ran the quota leak, hoping to buy some loyalty.
I was monitoring the internal dashboards—watching them swap names out, covering quotas while projecting mercy.
There were real bursts of joy, communities reconnecting, people calling family for the first time in years.
But I could see the math. For every cleared record, a new flag got assigned. It was algorithmic, brutal in its efficiency.
The resistance groups started swapping data. We charted it together, map by map—whole districts lit up, then dimmed as flags shifted.
Legacy news tried to wrap it in propaganda, but underground streams told the truth.
People felt real possibility for a heartbeat, then rage when the lie was exposed.
Sometimes I think hope is what the system fears most—truth isn't what breaks them, hope is.
I've always been accused of 'stirring things up.' Maybe that's true. I'd rather be tired and honest than numb and safe.
